framexml.data: Our past The Indus Valley Civilization developed around the plains of the River Indus in about 2600BCE. Harappa and Mohenjo Daro are two of the most famous archaeological sites of the Indus Valley Civilization. Archaeologists have found pieces of pottery, jewellery, clay figures, and seals at Harappa and Mohenjo Daro. Seals with inscriptions The Aryans came to the subcontinent from Central Asia around 1500BCE The Aryans brought a new culture to the subcontinent. They also brought a new language, Sanskrit, and a religion called Hinduism with them. The Persians came into the subcontinent during the 5th century Their capital here was Taxila. The Greeks under Alexander the Great defeated the Persians and crossed into the subcontinent through the Khyber Pass. The Greeks influenced the art and sculpture in Gandhara and Taxila. The Mauryans and the Kushans came to power after the Persians were defeated by the Greeks. Ashoka was the most famous Mauryan ruler. Kanishka was the most famous Kushan ruler. The Mauryans and the Kushans were followed by the Gupta dynasty. The Guptas built a large and powerful empire under Chandra Gupta. The Parthians and the Huns came into the subcontinent from the north-west. Harsha, the ruler of the Nanda dynasty, set up the Nalanda University. Most of the early people in this region were Hindus and Buddhists. Jainism also spread within India. Islam spread in the subcontinent with the arrival of Mohammad bin Qasim in the 8th century Mohenjo Daros Harappa The Aryans The Persians Taxila Gandhara Ashoka's edict pillar Coins from the Kushan period harsha Nalanda University ruins Mohammad bin Qasim Coins from the Gupta period
